thread.title: Corruption Currents: French Billionaire Questioned in Africa Bribery Probe

author: Ben DiPietro
title: Corruption Currents: French Billionaire Questioned in Africa Bribery Probe
text:
1 COMMENTS French businessman Vincent Bollore in Paris on April 19. Photo: REUTERS/Charles Platiau/File Photo
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories vi a our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
A Michigan garbage-industry executive received five-and-a-half years in prison Monday after earlier pleading guilty to bribing politicians and stealing from his company. A sobbing Chuck Rizzo apologized and said he was “ too focused on getting ahead .” (DFP, MDN)
A jury convicted a lawyer Tuesday of bribing a New York police sergeant. The attorney for John Chambers says he will appeal . (NYP, NYDN)
Money Laundering:
A company headed by one of France’s richest men denies claims it engaged in corruption and meddled in elections in Africa. Billionaire Vincent Bolloré was taken into custody for questioning on Tuesday. Companies associated with Mr. Bolloré saw their share prices fall in Tuesday trading. (Telegraph, Bloomberg, BBC, Street)
Latvia’s prime minister says the country has until July to show progress in its fight against money laundering in the banking sector. (LSM)
A U.S. federal court says a class-action money-laundering lawsuit against cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase must be held in open court and not in private arbitration. (Cointelgraph)
A former Mexican governor charged with drug trafficking and money laundering in the U.S. says he can’t afford an attorney. Tomas Yarrington was extradited from Italy to face charges. (MSA, KVEO)
The Hong Kong Monetary Authority in the past 10 months froze HK$2.8 million ($356,800) it believes is tied to money laundering or terrorist financing. (EJI)
Cybercrime/Privacy:
Some Chinese activists are looking to blockchain to avoid surveillance by the government. (Bloomberg)
The U.S. may enact sanctions against Kaspersky Lab, which already is banned from some government contracts because of its alleged ties to Russia. The company denies the claims. (CyberScoop)
Sanctions:
Some U.S. allies are suffering after sanctions were placed on Russian military exports . (Reuters)
Iran’s president warns of “ severe consequences ” should the U.S. withdraw from the nuclear agreement. Israel is lobbying Italy to end its objection to additional sanctions against Iran. (Politico, JP)
Whistleblowers:
So you want to be a whistleblower? First thing: Learn the rules. (CT)
The whistleblower who exposed a Catholic Church sex-abuse scandal in Chile is in Italy to meet with Pope Francis. (AP)
General Anti-Corruption:
A former speaker of Indonesia’s parliament was sentenced to 15 years in prison for theft of public funds. Setya Novanto was accused of stealing $170 million. (AJ, AP)
The former head of the anticorruption unit in Egypt was sentenced to five years in prison on Tuesday for “spreading news that harms the armed forces.” The man’s lawyer said he will appeal. (MEE)
A drug agent discusses the time he captured Mexican drug kingpin Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman. (BBC)
A judge in Nigeria was ordered to defend himself against corruption allegations; the judge previously pleaded not guilty. (SR)
A report into corruption in tennis will be released this week. (BBC)
Closing arguments began Monday in the fraud trial of four former Wilmington Trust Corp. executives. (AP)
